title: Azadithiolate cofactor
text: An azadithiolate cofactor is an <a href="anion">anion</a> with the formula NH(CH2S)22−. It is used as a <a href="cofactor%20%28biochemistry%29">cofactor</a> in the [FeFe] <a href="hydrogenase">hydrogenase</a>s, <a href="enzymes">bacterial enzymes</a> responsible for the reversible reduction of 2 H+ to H2. As a cofactor, the two <a href="thiol">thiolate</a> <a href="functional%20group">functional group</a>s are bound to each of the two irons in the <a href="active%20site">active site</a> of the enzyme in a <a href="bridging%20ligand">bridging fashion</a>. The <a href="amine">amine</a> functional group serves as an <a href="acid-base%20reaction">acid/base</a> to transfer H+ from the solution to the active site. The proton transfer function of this cofactor is of great importance to the activity of the hydrogenase enzyme, as H2 evolution will not occur if the amine is not present.
